repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Ain Temouchent Emergency
            Earthquake Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Ain Temouchent emergency
            earthquake recovery project for Algeria were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: it is important to ensure
            that the proposed investments are aligned to the project
            development objective. There was some debate about whether a
            project for emergency reconstruction such as this should
            have included a new waste water treatment plant in the first
            place. It is important to carefully select the appropriate
            procurement and implementation procedures. An assessment of
            local resources is required to ensure that the best
            procurement procedures are adopted under the circumstances.
            It is important that emergency operations such as this
            project be able to depend on decentralized implementation
            through existing sectoral institutions and capacity which is
            much more appropriate and effective than using a
            centrally-located project management unit or other ad hoc
            implementation arrangements. Finally, it is important to use
            the lessons identified from local project monitoring to
            inform national level decision-making and policy making.

repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Ain Temouchent Emergency
            Earthquake Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Ain Temouchent Emergency Earthquake
            Recovery Project aims to restore normal functioning of
            communities damaged by the December 22, 1999 earthquake in
            the Wilaya of Ain Temouchent and to increase national
            preparedness for future disasters. The project consists of
            five components. 1) Disaster organization and risk
            management will strengthen the institutional capacity of
            emergency management in Algeria to prepare for and manage
            the consequences of large-scale emergencies, and to promote
            a nationwide, comprehensive risk management strategy. The
            component will finance acquisition of emergency response and
            search-and-rescue capacity in Algeria through the purchase
            of specialized equipment and training in the use and
            maintenance of the equipment. 2) The housing component will
            assist the government in the reconstruction of permanent
            housing in the areas affected by the earthquake. 3)
            Technical infrastructure will restore essential
            infrastructure for the benefit of the population at large
            and in particular for the population affected by the
            earthquake. The component includes the design and
            supervision of infrastructure construction. 4) Social
            infrastructure will finance the reconstruction of public
            buildings which provide vital social services, including
            schools, hospitals, recreation centers, and government
            offices. 5) Project implementation will finance the creation
            and maintenance of a Project Coordination Unit during the implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Ain Temouchent Earthquake
            Emergency Reconstruction Project : environment management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
In response to future catastrophic
            events, the Ain Temouchent Earthquake Emergency
            Reconstruction Project aims at contributing not only, to
            reconstruction purposes in Algeria, but at strengthening
            institutional capacity, through the financing of disaster
            organization, and risk management. This Environmental
            Management Plan (EMP) will support, and improve the quality
            of the project, ensuring stakeholders' participation,
            namely that of the environment protection authority, and of
            local communities, and, strengthening the capacity to
            address environmental responsiveness under disaster
            circumstances. Mitigating measures address: 1) institutional
            issues, modifying emergency procedures, through technical
            assistance, and training, to integrate environmental
            protection in the design, and implementation of emergency
            programs; 2) technical infrastructure, and housing
            rehabilitation, assessing new sites - including landscaping,
            and re-vegetation -, and, auditing drainage, and wastewater
            treatment plants, for rehabilitation, or construction of new
            wastewater facilities; and, 3) social infrastructures, to
            prevent health hazards, through the rehabilitation of
            sanitary, schools, and public facilities, integrating
            technical specifications in procurement works.
